ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The class was taught through a bi-weekly virtual seminar.
None
N/A
Personal meetings with professor.
Virtual synchronous lecture, breakout rooms for discussion, large group discussion

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about various interpretations of the Christian Bible and how these interpretations have shaped individuals, society, and the world. I developed my writings skills and learned how to put texts/authors in conversation with one another.
Learned more about contemporary and historical uses of the Bible; engaged in discussion with peers about particularly controversial topics surrounding the Bible; critical analysis in writing
I learned how to historically contextualize and analyze uses of biblical scripture.
I became a better writer and learned skills that are important for writing papers in the humanities, such as how to conduct a positive versus normative analysis.

This course was amazing. The material was consistently engaging, and I learned how to academically analyze New Testament passages and uses of the New Testament in popular culture, including in politics, in race relations, in the characterization of women, etc. I also learned how to journal academically, writing my learnings from the classes weekly. I also learned how to contextualize a specific use of scripture and write about its importance in the context of readings from the course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Great material, good feedback, work is difficult but definitely doable, a lot of readings but you will love all of them
Weaknesses: I wish there were informal discussion sessions outside of class time for just students to discuss readings or essays on our own

Strengths: good survey of the historical and contemporary uses of the Bible, good guidance throughout writing papers, very knowledgable professor

Weaknesses: feedback throughout the course was sometimes not very clear, lectures sometimes felt disconnected with papers, lectures sometimes lack structure

Strengths: you become a better writer

Weaknesses: can get kind of monotone sometimes, course material is really interesting but when listening to lectures on antiquity it can be tough to stay engaged
I enjoyed the interesting array of readings that we had and that we got to make presentations in class.

Strengths include the format of the course, a new topic each week with readings and two discussions over the same topic. Professor Nasrallah is an amazing discussion facilitator, and offered relevant and challenging resources for us to discuss. This course is my ideal course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I felt that this class handled Covid Discussion Sections the best as the professor and the teaching fellow were amazing at guiding the discussion and keeping students involved.
The virtual seminar-style was quite successful - I felt very engaged during class and could also freely express my thoughts without concern.
Teaching staff did the most they could given the circumstances (eg: breakout rooms, mini presentations)
I felt this course was very well structured for distance learning, as the professor made sure to accommodate our needs.

The virtual format of this course did not prevent students from engaging critically, which I think is because we took time each class to check in with everyone, which fostered a sense of community and trust within the course. This is the only course of mine that did that, and I was able to feel the difference in engagement in this course because of it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Even if you have no experience with the Christian Bible, this course will have something to offer to you, whether it is discussions on race, the environment, or politics. It truly embodies a liberal arts education. Also, it will help you improve your writing and discussion skills. I never felt like I didnt know enough to speak in discussion sections or felt discouraged from doing so.

I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in getting a broad overview of certain controversial topics of the Bible. However, I would say that having some prior knowledge of the Bible is beneficial and might almost be necessary.

Yes, only 3 short papers and interesting readings. If you're not interested in learning about the bible and its modern uses though, you wont be able to stay engaged all the time. Professor is very accomplished and  communicates well.
Yes I would recommend this class to anyone who would like to improve their writing skills and learn more about the history and contemporary topics in Christian studies.

Yes! I received clear feedback and mentorship, the class structure was very organized and allowed us to deeply engage with a new topic every week. This was my favorite course this year, and I would take it again in a heart beat if I could.
Yes, both instructors were incredibly helpful and willing to meet with students to talk outside of class. Very interesting topics were discussed!
